newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIA PRODUCT SWAPS - FUEL OIL UP ON FRESH SUPPORT.
newsitem.headline: ASIA PRODUCT SWAPS - FUEL OIL UP ON FRESH SUPPORT.

text.p: Singapore fuel oil swaps rose at midday on Wednesday amid firmer overnight crude values and fresh buying interest in the physical market, traders said.
"Fuel is going up because supplies are tight in Singapore and there are signs that China is coming back to buy," one trader said.
September fuel oil was last quoted at $104.25/$105.00 per tonne, up from Tuesday's $103.50/$104.50, brokers said. It traded late Tuesday to a high of $103.75, they said.
September has gained about $1.50 per tonne since Monday.
The firmer prices were partly due to support in the physical market from more than one player.

In the physical market, trading broke clear of the previous range of between $102.00 and $103.00 per tonne after a 20,000-tonne cargo traded at $103.50 on a free-on-board Singapore basis, up $1.00 from Friday's traded level.
A Singapore trader bought the September 7-11 lifting cargo from a European major. Another buyer was seen for a end August cargo at $102.50 per tonne.
Also the emergence of Chinese traders on the swaps market picking up several September and October lots has led to speculation that China will re-enter the market to buy physical cargoes.
The gas oil was edged up slightly in line with the firmer crude and was last quoted up 10 cents at $23.40/$23.50 per barrel with no deals seen, brokers said.
The jet fuel/gas oil spread or regrade is coming under pressure due to forced sales of physical jet fuel by traders who do not have enough storage space.
Traders said the sales on Tuesday of two 100,000 barrel cargoes at $22.80 per barrel was in part due to this.
Sellers are increasingly being forced to turnover their cargoes in Singapore tanks as new supplies arrive from the Middle East.
The September regrade is valued steady at $1.00 but the prompt August regrade is valued at about 40 cents from $1.20 a week ago, brokers said.
